title: How to Protect Yourself From Cross Contamination

content: The risk of cross-contamination can be concerning when you get diagnosed with food allergies. It can be a difficult ground to manage, as some people risk eating food that may contain their allergen while others don’t take any risks at all. I hope by the end of the blog post, I will have some answers to your concerns and you can effectively manage your allergies safely.
Cross-contamination can occur when allergens are accidentally transferred from one food or surface to another, potentially causing a severe allergic reaction or even anaphylactic shock.

This can happen due to multiple factors, such as shared utensils, surfaces, cooking equipment or even when someone touches your allergen then touches you or the food you eat! Can feel overwhelming, right?

Let’s start with food that has the “may contain” warning on it and whether you should risk eating it when you have an allergy. Personally, I think it depends on the severity of your allergy and what your doctor has said is safe for you. I don’t eat anything that says “may contain” on the packaging, as it's too much of a risk for me.

content: When I was a teenager, I went to an anaphylaxis workshop in the U.K., and they showed us a Cadbury bar with the “may contain nuts" warning on the back of the packaging. When the customer opened the chocolate bar, you could see a massive peanut sticking out of it! To this day, this image has imprinted on me, and it scarred me, if I’m honest.

Eating at home with an allergy should be a safe haven, as you know what ingredients are going into the food and have control over making sure there is no risk of cross-contamination. However, this can be difficult when living with housemates who might not understand cross-contamination and its risks. I lived in a seven-bedroom house with strangers when I first moved to London. One of the first things I communicated with everyone when I moved into the house was to talk them through my allergy, the risks of cross-contamination, and how dangerous it could be for me if they cooked with nuts.

content: I was very lucky that all my housemates took my allergy very seriously. There were a few occasions where they would cook nuts in the kitchen when I wasn’t around. I made it very clear to them that if they did, they had to be very thorough when cleaning cooking equipment and plates to reduce any risk of cross-contamination.

What I learned was communication is key but it’s also important to remind them regularly, as people can easily forget about your food allergy. I used to take this personally, but you have to remember that everyone has a lot going on in their own lives and it can be easy to forget other people’s needs sometimes! On one occasion, they used peanut butter on mouse traps around the kitchen. I nearly had a heart attack when I found out. The risk of cross-contamination if the trap didn’t work and the mouse was running over the work surfaces! Once I communicated this to my housemate, they understood and changed it straight away. Never feel embarrassed to speak up and communicate your allergy, even more so when you live with other people!

sections.heading: Eating at Restaurants
content: A study found that a significant percentage of restaurant meals tested positive for unintended allergens due to cross-contact, highlighting the risks of dining out for individuals with food allergies ( Journal of Allergy and Clinical Immunology ). Eating out is about reducing risks of cross-contamination by eating somewhere where your allergens are not on the menu and making sure to communicate your allergy clearly. However, some of the restaurants where I’ve eaten have nuts present on the menu. If this is the case, communication is key.

You have to communicate very clearly to the staff when eating out to make sure they understand the seriousness of your allergy. If staff members don’t understand the risk of cross-contamination and you don’t feel they have taken what you said seriously, then please don’t put your life in someone else’s hands. You always have the option to leave! It's important to go with your gut feeling, especially when eating out.

content: I’m currently traveling in South America, and food allergies are even a growing concern here! I was surprised at the amount of people who were aware of food allergies when I've been eating out (which has been most meals). However, I’ve found it to be more difficult in rural parts of South America when food allergy awareness isn’t as present.

To round it up, the importance of continuous vigilance and staying informed about food allergy management is key, but the most powerful weapon at your disposal to protect yourself is communicating. Use your voice and never feel embarrassed to speak about it. There are also spaces where you can find additional resources and support, including allergy organizations and online communities.
